lines.text: Toni, don't get one thing wrong. I still love you.
You don't need to say anything because there isn't anything left to say. If you'd even told me - but lying. You've lost your size, Jerry, and I could never chase trains with a little man.
Toni, I do love you.
That's very sweet, but I'm afraid we've missed the train.
Nice ham.
You said that in Vienna.
Not about ham. That was wiener schnitzel. I distinctly remember arguing the relationship of a cow to a calf.
Jerry, you're an idiot.
You said that in Vienna.
And London and Rome and a few other places.
You've always said there was no time for anything else but fooling.
Toni, we're rich.
Again? That's nice.
This letter's from my brother-in-law. He's been looking after the baby.
Baby? What baby?
My baby.
Wait a minute, Jerry, do you mean you have a child?
Yes, didn't I tell you? She must be, uh, five or six by now. I don't know exactly.
For a man who talks so much you say very little.
Do you wish we were settled down and this was our kid?
Do you?
No.
I don't think I do, either, but I wish we wanted to.
You're tired of chasing trains and all that?
I've been sailing my boat around the island. I wanted to see where the pirates camped last night.
Do you keep your boat padlocked to the dock so the pirates won't steal it?
No, Uncle George keeps it padlocked so I won't sail it alone. He's afraid. You see, I didn't really sail around the island, not honor bright.
Honor bright?
Yes, you can only say that when it's honest-to-goodness true.
Who taught you that?
My mother.
Daddy doesn't know anything about raising children.
Hello, my boy. Where are you staying?
Oh, uh, I hadn't decided yet. I'll look you up at the bank tomorrow.
At the bank. Well, goodbye, Penny.
Goodbye, Uncle Felix.
And who's Uncle Felix?
He's a good friend of ours. We like him. He bought one of Daddy's goldmines.
Toni, I know what's eating you. You think I haven't got any business with that kid. Well, you're wrong, dead wrong. You haven't got a thing to worry about, you wait and see.

I see, and what's in the past is all in the past. No more beating debts or dodging gentlemen in uniforms or chasing trains. No more hurried departures from unpleasant business. Your only concern is for your daughter's future, and you want above everything to make her happy.
Absolutely, dear.
So you sold Uncle Felix the phony goldmine to get the money for the good time. Stop lying, Jerry.
Lying?
Yes, stop lying. It doesn't become you. I know exactly what you were thinking - fun, excitement, thrills. You wouldn't know a responsibility if you fell over one in the street.
Well, supposing it was like that, what difference does it make?
You've got to mean it. You're her father, and she's yours, so you've got to quit selling goldmines. You can't take a child out of a good home and throw her into a life like this.
Think of that child.
I am.
I've decided to write a book. "My Breathless Years."
Will I be in it?
Yes, but you won't stay long. I'll kill you off early.
Not getting tired of it, by any chance?
Never a dull moment, dear.
Penny, this is sort of your new mother. And Toni, I guess you'd say this is sort of our new daughter.
I guess you would.
A bathroom's a bathroom. You don't live in it.
Here, I'm giving you this gold for an old pair of skates.
They aren't old. They're real ball-bearing, see?
Do you know where gold comes from? From a hole in the ground, way down deep. They take a long time to find out. Months. Sometimes even years.
Oh, all right. Here.

[to Toni]
There's nothing funny about this.

[to Penny]
Penny, what are you doing?
Putting on skates.
Where did you get them?
Oh, I just got them.
I think you'd better give them back.
She gave me this gold for keeps. I don't want them back.
Let me see that. Real gold, Penny?
Yes.
Honor bright, Penny?
You aren't talking about Penny. You're talking about yourself.
That isn't so.
Stop lying, Toni. It doesn't become you, either. I took you out of a good home and into a life like this.
You didn't take me. I wanted to go.
And instead of a decent husband, I gave you a guy who chases trains and deals in phony goldmines.

If I want you, I'll have to take you as you are. I don't like it, Jerry, but I've been without you for a long time and I like that less. I know what I want and I don't get it, so I'm gonna do the next best thing. I'm gonna sell goldmines and chase trains with you for as long as you want me. If the trains wind up in rather ugly places, that's all right, too. We'll both be there togehter.
Well, that wins. I guess I'm gonna get a job now. I guess I'll be anything you want, Toni, if you love me that much.
[repeated line]
Who do you love?
Why did you let me pull one over on you in New York?
Because I knew that one day I would get my money back. With interest.
Suppose you turn right around and repeat that slight-of-hand act. There's nothing in my eye, and if I'm not mistaken, that's a cop up there.
But you don't want to talk to a cop any more than I do. That's why I let you swindle me, so that when this day came, you couldn't call a cop.

There's something phony about you, Mr. Day. I've taken the trouble to ask a lot of questions about you. You don't make much money and you spend a lot. That sounds like adventure to me, and if that's the case, Penny will get in your way somday. And when that happens, I want to take her. I'm kind of a lonely old coot. I've plenty of money and no one to spend it on. And that child is the one human being I've ever met whom I want around me as long as I live.
She's a friend of Penny's and a good one.
So am I. At least, I'm trying to be. Indirectly, of course. Why, that necklace must be worth, oh...
The answer is still no.
I shouldn't be saying this, I know, but if you know anything about my necklace, I'd like to know. I can call these lads off, and I'd do it too, for your kid.
Well, I'd like to help, Mrs. Crane, but I'm sure this is all we can do.
Did you steal that necklace? You must answer.
Oh.
Well?
Well what, dear?
Well, you must answer. Did you steal that necklace?
No, I didn't steal it.
Honor bright?
You're a funny one.
No, you must answer. That's the whole point. Honor bright?
Honor bright.
You don't need to tell me how lucky Penny is that you want to take care of her. Do you still want to?
I certainly do.
Permanately?
That's the only way I would consider it.
Then that's the way it'll be. So she can grow up into a very lovely lady.
Daddy, I wouldn't leave you if you didn't have Toni to take care of you.
I am not giving Penny a jailbird for a father.
